protocol_name: One-step growth curves for Cellulophaga phages
protocol_name_html: One-step growth curves for Cellulophaga phages
description: One-step growth curves are used to make determinations about the life cycle of a virus on a particular host.  By following a virus infection during one life cycle phase of host a growth curve can be constructed and the burst size can be calculated.
before_start: Before performing a one-step experiment, you need to determine when the host is growing exponentially.  You must also determine the titer of the phage lysate that will be used for the experiment.  These are described in the protocol.
affiliation: Matthew Sullivan Lab, University of Arizona, The Ohio State University

guidelines: Note: One-step growth experiment instructions are for MOI=0.1.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 2 of One-step growth curves for Cellulophaga phages
source_data.protocol_name: One-step growth curves for Cellulophaga phages
source_data.protocol_name_html: One-step growth curves for Cellulophaga phages
source_data.annotation: Take the T0 growth reading at 595nm using 200ul of culture, in duplicate.  Make sure the microtiter plate you are using is clean inside and out, with no scratches or spots on its surface, as it will interfere with the light reading.  Subtract the media blank reading from the culture reading to arrive at the OD595 for the culture.
source_data.thread_text: Take the T0 growth reading at 595nm using 200ul of culture, in duplicate.  Make sure the microtiter plate you are using is clean inside and out, with no scratches or spots on its surface, as it will interfere with the light reading.  Subtract the media blank reading from the culture reading to arrive at the OD595 for the culture.
source_data.body: Take the T0 growth reading at 595nm using 200ul of culture, in duplicate.  Make sure the microtiter plate you are using is clean inside and out, with no scratches or spots on its surface, as it will interfere with the light reading.  Subtract the media blank reading from the culture reading to arrive at the OD595 for the culture.

source_data.annotation: Graph the results as you go! It is best to infect the host in med-exponential (log linear) phase, when OD ≅ 0.02.

source_data.protocol_name_html: One-step growth curves for Cellulophaga phages
source_data.annotation: You can start with longer intervals (1–2 hours) until you start to see growth, then shorter intervals (15–30 minutes) until the growth starts to level off. If it’s taking a while, you can go back to reading at longer intervals.
source_data.thread_text: You can start with longer intervals (1–2 hours) until you start to see growth, then shorter intervals (15–30 minutes) until the growth starts to level off. If it’s taking a while, you can go back to reading at longer intervals.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 1 of Centrifuged Sample Steps
source_data.annotation: Once you know how many phages to expect, you know what dilutions of your early samples to plate to get good counts For example, if the T0 expected concentration is 10<sup>4</sup>, there should be 100 plaques if you plate 100 μl of a 10<sup>-1</sup> dilution.
source_data.thread_text: Once you know how many phages to expect, you know what dilutions of your early samples to plate to get good counts For example, if the T0 expected concentration is 10<sup>4</sup>, there should be 100 plaques if you plate 100 μl of a 10<sup>-1</sup> dilution.
source_data.body: Once you know how many phages to expect, you know what dilutions of your early samples to plate to get good counts For example, if the T0 expected concentration is 10<sup>4</sup>, there should be 100 plaques if you plate 100 μl of a 10<sup>-1</sup> dilution.
source_data.affiliation: University of Arizona

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 1 of Centrifuged Sample Steps
source_data.annotation: Note that if you are using a different MOI, you will need to calculate the expected number of phage at T0 to guide you in what dilution to plate This will depend on the total volume of the initial infection (ie, the volume of cells plus phages) So the concentration at T0 should be total phage added/volume of infection, divided by 1000 (for the 1:1000 dilution) Convert this to phages per ml.
source_data.thread_text: Note that if you are using a different MOI, you will need to calculate the expected number of phage at T0 to guide you in what dilution to plate This will depend on the total volume of the initial infection (ie, the volume of cells plus phages) So the concentration at T0 should be total phage added/volume of infection, divided by 1000 (for the 1:1000 dilution) Convert this to phages per ml.

source_data.protocol_name_html: One-step growth curves for Cellulophaga phages
source_data.annotation: At later time points, more dilutions will need to be plated. On the first trial, be generous with what you plate (ie, plate 10<sup>-2</sup>, 10<sup>-3</sup>, 10<sup>-4</sup>, 10<sup>-5</sup>) and use the results as a guide for what you should plate in repeat experiments.
source_data.thread_text: At later time points, more dilutions will need to be plated. On the first trial, be generous with what you plate (ie, plate 10<sup>-2</sup>, 10<sup>-3</sup>, 10<sup>-4</sup>, 10<sup>-5</sup>) and use the results as a guide for what you should plate in repeat experiments.

components.data: Take the FREE phage average of the time points on the plateau before the burst (A)
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Take the FREE phage average of the time points on the plateau before the burst (A)

components.data: Take the FREE phage average of the time points on the plateau after the burst (B)
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Take the FREE phage average of the time points on the plateau after the burst (B)

components.data: Subtract A from B; This is the total burst or new phages released (C)
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Subtract A from B; This is the total burst or new phages released (C)

components.data: Divide C by the number of infecting phage (TOTAL phages at T0 minus FREE at T0); This is the burst size
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Divide C by the number of infecting phage (TOTAL phages at T0 minus FREE at T0); This is the burst size
